model_completion: Born in 1908, Edward R. Murrow was an American journalist and broadcaster. He was the first director of the United States Information Agency (USIA), which was established by President Dwight Eisenhower in 1953. Murrow's most famous broadcast was his See It Now series, which ran from 1951 to 1957. In 1954, he won a Peabody Award for his coverage of Senator Joseph McCarthy's anti-communist campaign.

Born in 1923, Stephanie Louise Kwolek was the first woman to invent Kevlar, a material used in bulletproof vests and helmets. She was also the first woman to be inducted into the National Inventors Hall of Fame. Kwolek worked as a research chemist at DuPont for over 40 years.

Harvey Milk was born in New York City on May 22, 1930. He moved to San Francisco in 1951 and became the first openly gay man elected to public office in California. In 1978, he was assassinated along with Mayor George Moscone by Dan White, a former city supervisor.

Born in Jamshedpur, India, Priyanka Chopra was raised in Mumbai. She began her career as a model at the age of 17 and went on to win the Miss World pageant in 2000. In 2003, she made her acting debut with the film 'The Hero: Love Story of a Spy.' Since then, she has appeared in several Bollywood films, including 'Fashion,' 'Dostana,' and 'Don.' In 2015, she starred in the American TV series 'Quantico,' which earned her a Golden Globe nomination for Best Actress.

Darius Khondji was born in Tehran, Iran in 1955. He moved to Paris at the age of 20 and began working as a cinematographer. His first film was 'The Return of Martin Guerre' (1982). Since then, he has worked on many films including 'Seven', 'The Talented Mr. Ripley', 'Eyes Wide Shut', 'Mulholland Drive', 'In the Mood for Love', 'Good Night, and Good Luck', and 'There Will Be Blood'.

Born in 1959, Evo Morales was the first indigenous president of Bolivia. He was elected as the President of Bolivia in 2006 and re-elected in 2009. In 2014, he won his third term as the President of Bolivia. He has been an advocate for social justice and human rights.

George Washington was born on February 22, 1732 in Westmoreland County, Virginia. He was the son of Augustine and Mary Ball Washington. His father died when he was 11 years old, and his older brother Lawrence took over as the head of the family. In 1748, George enrolled at the College of William & Mary, but dropped out after two years to work for his brother. In 1752, George married Martha Custis, who was 26 years old. They had six children together. During the French and Indian War, George served as an officer in the Virginia militia. After the war, he became a land surveyor. In 1759, George was elected to the House of Burgesses, where he served until 1774. In 1775, George was appointed commander-in-chief of the Continental Army.

Frida Kahlo was born in Mexico City on July 6, 1907. She was the daughter of a German-Jewish father and a Mexican mother. At the age of six, she contracted polio, which left her right leg crippled. In 1925, she married Diego Rivera, one of the most famous muralists in Mexico. They had a stormy marriage, but they remained together until Diego's death in 1957. During their marriage, Frida suffered from miscarriages, stillbirths, and physical pain. She also had an affair with Leon Trotsky, who was exiled to Mexico after the Russian Revolution. Frida died in 1954 at the age of 47.

Born in Ljubljana, Slovenia, in 1949, Slavoj Žižek was raised by his mother after his father died during World War II. He studied philosophy at the University of Ljubljana and later received his PhD from the London School of Economics. In 1987, he became a professor of philosophy at the University of Ljubljana. Žižek has written more than twenty books on topics such as psychoanalysis, ideology, and politics. His most famous work is 'Living in the End Times,' which was published in 2010.

Born in Rogers, Texas, on January 5, 1931, Alvin Ailey was the son of a sharecropper and a domestic worker. He began his dance training at age 12 with Marion Cuyjet, who taught him modern dance techniques. In 1949, he moved to New York City to study at the American Dance Center. In 1954, Ailey founded the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, which has become one of the most popular dance companies in the world. The company's repertoire includes more than 200 dances, including "Revelations," which is considered to be one of the greatest modern dance pieces ever created. Ailey died on December 1, 1989.

Born in 1990, Yuna Kim is a South Korean figure skater who won the gold medal at the 2010 Winter Olympics. She was the first female figure skater from Asia to win an Olympic gold medal. Kim began skating when she was five years old and joined the national team when she was nine. In 2007, she became the first Asian woman to win the World Figure Skating Championships.

Born in Hong Kong, Jackie Chan was raised by his grandparents after his parents separated when he was only five years old. He began his career as a stuntman and later became an actor, director, producer, and singer. His first major role was in the 1978 film 'Snake in the Eagle's Shadow.' In 1980, he starred in 'Drunken Master,' which was a huge success. Since then, he has appeared in over 200 films, including 'Rumble in the Bronx,' 'Police Story,' and 'Shanghai Noon.'

Born in Poland, Marie Curie was the first woman to win a Nobel Prize, and the only person to win two Nobel Prizes. She won the Nobel Prize in Physics in 1903, for her work on radioactivity, and the Nobel Prize in Chemistry in 1911, for her discovery of radium and polonium. In 1921, she became the first female professor at the University of Paris.

Born in Trier, Germany on May 5, 1818, Karl Marx was a German philosopher and economist who developed the theory of communism. He wrote The Communist Manifesto with Friedrich Engels in 1848. In 1849, he moved to London where he lived until his death in 1883.

Rachel Maddow was born in 1973, and grew up in Castro Valley, California. She graduated from Stanford University with a degree in politics, and later received her doctorate in political science from Oxford University. In 2005, she began hosting the show 'The Rachel Maddow Show' on MSNBC. The show has won several awards, including an Emmy for Outstanding News Discussion & Analysis.

Born in 1975, Jamie Oliver is an English chef and television personality. He was born in Essex, England, and grew up in Clavering. At the age of 16, he started working at The Cricketers restaurant in Clavering. In 1993, he moved to London to work as a pastry chef at Antonio Carluccio's Neal Street Restaurant. In 1994, he opened his first restaurant, The River Café, with his friend Jools Holland. In 1999, he published his first cookbook, 'The Naked Chef.' In 2000, he hosted his own show, 'The Naked Chef,' which ran for three seasons. In 2001, he released his second cookbook, 'Jamie's Kitchen.' In 2002, he launched his own line of food products, including ready-made meals, sauces, and snacks.

Born in Cambridge, England on June 5, 1883, John Maynard Keynes was an economist and one of the most influential thinkers of the 20th century. He was educated at Eton College and King's College, Cambridge. In 1919, he became the chief economic adviser to the British government. His best-known work, 'The General Theory of Employment, Interest and Money,' was published in 1936. Keynes died on April 21, 1946.

Born in New Haven, Connecticut, on September 15, 1852, Edward Alexander Bouchet was the first African American to earn a PhD from Yale University. He also became the first African American to receive a doctorate degree in physics. In 1876, he graduated from Yale with a bachelor's degree in mathematics and physics. After graduation, he taught at several schools, including Wilberforce University, Howard University, and Fisk University. In 1906, he became the president of the newly founded Howard University. He died on February 25, 1918.

Hammurabi was the sixth king of Babylon, and he ruled from 1792 to 1750 BCE. He was known as the Lawgiver because he created the first written code of laws in history. The Code of Hammurabi was inscribed on a black stone stele, which is now kept at the Louvre Museum in Paris.

Born in Germany, Albert Einstein was a theoretical physicist who developed the theory of relativity and contributed greatly to the development of quantum mechanics. He received the Nobel Prize for Physics in 1921. In 1933, he fled Nazi Germany and moved to the United States. He died in 1955.

Ludwig van Beethoven was born in Bonn, Germany on December 16, 1770. He was the son of Johann and Maria Magdalena Beethoven. His father was a musician who taught him to play the piano at an early age. At the age of 21, he moved to Vienna, Austria, where he studied with Haydn and other great composers. In 1809, he became deaf, but continued to compose. He died in 1827.

Born in Ohio in 1931, Toni Morrison was the first African-American woman to win the Nobel Prize for Literature. She grew up in Lorain, Ohio, and attended Howard University, where she received her BA in English. In 1955, she married Harold Morrison, and they had two children together. After graduating from Cornell University with an MA in English, she taught at Texas Southern University, Yale University, and Princeton University. Her first novel, 'The Bluest Eye,' was published in 1970. It was followed by 'Sula' (1974), 'Song of Solomon' (1977), 'Tar Baby' (1981), 'Beloved' (1987), 'Jazz' (1992), 'Paradise' (1997), 'Love' (2003), and 'Home' (2012).

Born in Maryland, Michael Phelps was raised by his mother and grandmother after his father left the family when he was young. He began swimming at age seven, and won his first national championship at age 15. In 2004, Phelps became the youngest male swimmer to win an Olympic gold medal. At the 2008 Beijing Olympics, Phelps set a record for most gold medals won by any athlete in one Olympic Games, with eight. He also holds the world record for most career gold medals.

Octavia Estelle Butler was born on June 22, 1947 in Pasadena, California. She was the first African-American woman to win a Hugo Award for her novel 'Kindred' (1979). Her other works include 'Parable of the Sower' (1993), 'Fledgling' (2005), and 'Kindred' (2008). Octavia Butler died on February 24, 2006 at the age of 58.

Born in London, England, Christiane Amanpour is the daughter of a British father and an Iranian mother. She attended school in England and France, and later studied journalism at the University of Rhode Island. In 1983, she began working for CNN as a correspondent based in London. She has covered many major news events, including the Gulf War, the fall of the Berlin Wall, the Rwandan genocide, and the Iraq War. In 2006, she was named chief international correspondent for CNN.

Diego Armando Maradona was born on October 30, 1960 in Buenos Aires, Argentina. He is considered one of the greatest football players of all time. Maradona started playing football at the age of 8 and joined Argentinos Juniors when he was 15. In 1976, he made his debut for the national team. Maradona led Argentina to win the World Cup in 1986, and won the Golden Ball award as the best player of the tournament. He also played for Napoli in Italy from 1984-1991, and helped them win two Serie A titles. Maradona retired from football in 1997, but returned to play for Dorados de Sinaloa in Mexico in 2010.

Judy Garland was born Frances Ethel Gumm in Minnesota on June 10, 1922. She began performing at the age of two and made her first film appearance at the age of three. In 1935, she signed with MGM Studios and became one of the studio's biggest stars. Her most famous role was as Dorothy in 'The Wizard of Oz.' She died of an accidental overdose of barbiturates in 1969.

Thomas Edward Patrick Brady, Jr., was born on August 3, 1977 in San Mateo, California. He is an American football quarterback for the New England Patriots of the National Football League (NFL). Brady played college football at Michigan and was drafted by the Patriots in the sixth round of the 2000 NFL Draft. In his first season with the Patriots, he led them to win Super Bowl XXXVI. Since then, he has won five Super Bowls, including four Super Bowls with the Patriots. Brady is one of only two players to win five Super Bowl MVP awards, along with Charles Haley.

Born in Los Angeles, California on October 21, 1980, Kim Kardashian is the daughter of attorney Robert Kardashian and actress Kris Jenner. She has two sisters, Kourtney and Khloe, and one brother, Rob. In 2007, she married music producer Damon Thomas, but they divorced in 2004. In 2011, she married rapper Kanye West, and they have a daughter named North.

Hakeem Olajuwon was born in Lagos, Nigeria on January 21, 1963. He moved to the United States at age 18 and attended the University of Houston. In 1984, he was drafted by the NBA's Houston Rockets as the first overall pick. He won two NBA championships with the Rockets in 1994 and 1995. He also won the NBA MVP award in 1994. After his retirement from basketball, he became an assistant coach for the Toronto Raptors.

Agatha Christie was born in Torquay, England on September 15, 1890. She was the daughter of an American mother and a British father. Her childhood was spent in Devon, where she developed a love for literature. In 1914, she married Archibald Christie, and they had two children. During World War I, she worked as a nurse at a hospital in London. After the war, she began writing novels. Her first novel, 'The Mysterious Affair at Styles,' was published in 1920. It introduced her famous detective character, Hercule Poirot. The book became a bestseller, and it was followed by many other successful novels. Agatha Christie wrote over 70 books during her lifetime, and her works have been translated into more than 100 languages.

Born in Tupelo, Mississippi, on January 8, 1935, Elvis Aaron Presley was the son of Vernon and Gladys Presley. He had an older brother, Jessie Garon, who died at birth. In 1948, the family moved to Memphis, Tennessee, where Elvis attended Humes High School. At the age of 18, he joined the United States Army, but was discharged after two years due to a high fever. After his discharge, he returned to Memphis, and began performing at local clubs. His first record, 'That's All Right', was released in 1954. In 1956, he signed with RCA Records, and released his first album, 'Elvis Presley'. The following year, he made his film debut in 'Love Me Tender'.

Born in Gary, Indiana, on August 29, 1958, Michael Jackson was the seventh child of the Jackson family. He began his career with his brothers as part of The Jackson 5. In 1971, they signed with Motown Records and released their first album, 'Got to Be There.' Their second album, 'ABC,' became a number one hit in 1972. After leaving Motown, Michael went solo and released his first album, 'Off the Wall,' in 1979. His next album, 'Thriller,' was released in 1982, and it became the best-selling album of all time. Michael Jackson died on June 25, 2009, at the age of 50.

Born in 1959, Paul Farmer is an American physician and anthropologist who has dedicated his life to fighting poverty and disease in Haiti and other developing countries. He is the co-founder of Partners In Health (PIH), a nonprofit organization that provides health care services to people living in poor communities around the world. Farmer was also the chief of the Department of Medical Anthropology at Harvard University. He received the MacArthur Foundation 'genius' grant in 2003.

Born in 1929, Milton Glaser is an American graphic designer and artist. He studied at the High School of Music & Art and the Cooper Union. In 1954, he founded Pushpin Studios with his partner Edward Sorel. His most famous work is the 'I Love New York' logo.

Amelia Earhart was born on July 24, 1897 in Atchison, Kansas. She was the first woman to fly solo across the Atlantic Ocean and the first person to fly solo from Hawaii to California. In 1937, she disappeared while attempting to circumnavigate the globe. Her disappearance remains one of the greatest mysteries of the twentieth century.

Charles Lindbergh was born in Detroit, Michigan on February 4, 1902. He was the first person to fly solo across the Atlantic Ocean. In 1927, he flew from New York to Paris in his plane, The Spirit of St. Louis. Lindbergh received the Congressional Medal of Honor for this achievement. He also won the Pulitzer Prize for his book, 'We.' Lindbergh married Anne Morrow in 1929. They had four children together. Lindbergh died on August 26, 1974.

Born in Beijing, China, on April 26, 1963, Jet Li was the youngest of five children. His father was a cook and his mother was a seamstress. At age 8, he began training in wushu, a Chinese martial art. He won many competitions and became a national champion at age 11. In 1979, he joined the Beijing Wushu Team and went to train in Hong Kong. In 1982, he moved to the United States to study acting. He made his film debut in 1982 with 'The Shaolin Temple.' Since then, he has starred in over 100 films, including 'Fist of Legend,' 'Once Upon a Time in China,' and 'Kiss of the Dragon.'

Yo was born in New York City, and grew up in the Bronx. He started rapping at age 12, and released his first album, 'Yo!', when he was 16. His second album, 'No Limit Top Dogg,' was released in 1998. In 2000, he released his third album, 'Thug Holiday.'

Cleopatra was the last pharaoh of Ancient Egypt, and one of the most famous women in history. She was born in 69 BCE, and ruled from 51-30 BCE. Cleopatra was married to two Roman rulers, Julius Caesar and Mark Antony. She committed suicide by snake bite in 30 BCE.

Mary Baker Eddy was born in 1821, and grew up in New Hampshire. She married George Washington Glover in 1843, but they later divorced. In 1866, she founded the Christian Science Church, which teaches that illness is caused by false beliefs. Her book 'Science and Health with Key to the Scriptures' became a best-seller, and her church has over 500 churches worldwide.

Rafael Nadal was born in Manacor, Mallorca, Spain on June 3, 1986. He began playing tennis at the age of four and turned professional in 2001. In 2005, he won his first Grand Slam title at the French Open. Since then, he has won 14 Grand Slam titles, including 10 French Opens and two Wimbledon Championships. He also holds the record for most consecutive wins at the French Open with seven.

Roger Federer was born in Basel, Switzerland on August 8, 1981. He started playing tennis at the age of eight and turned professional in 1998. In 2003, he won his first Grand Slam title at Wimbledon. Since then, he has won 17 Grand Slam titles, including 5 Australian Open titles, 4 French Open titles, 6 US Open titles, and 2 Wimbledon titles. He also holds the record for most consecutive Grand Slam tournaments (23) won by a man.

Petra Cortright was born in 1986, and grew up in the San Francisco Bay Area. She received her BFA from the University of California, Santa Barbara, and her MFA from the University of Southern California. Her work has been exhibited at the Museum of Modern Art, New York; the Whitney Museum of American Art, New York; the Hammer Museum, Los Angeles; the Museum of Contemporary Art, Los Angeles; the Walker Art Center, Minneapolis; the Wexner Center for the Arts, Columbus; the Museum of Contemporary Canadian Art, Toronto; and the New Museum, New York.

Born in Austria, Wolfgang Puck moved to the United States at age 14 and began working as a dishwasher. He later attended the Culinary Institute of America and worked for several restaurants before opening his own restaurant, Spago, in Los Angeles in 1982. In 1997, he opened the first Wolfgang Puck Express in an airport. Today, he has more than 30 restaurants around the world.

Born in London, England on July 30, 1970, Christopher Nolan was raised by his mother and father, who were both teachers. He attended the University College London, where he studied English literature. In 1996, he directed his first feature film, Following, which was followed by Memento (2000), Insomnia (2002), The Prestige (2006), and The Dark Knight (2008). His most recent films are Inception (2010) and The Dark Knight Rises (2012).

Born in 1950, Jenny Holzer is an American artist and writer who works with the mediums of painting, sculpture, installation art, performance art, and text. She is best known for her public art installations that feature words and phrases on electronic displays or printed on placards. In 2006, she was awarded the Leone d'Oro prize at the Venice Biennale.

Sol LeWitt was born in Hartford, Connecticut in 1928. He studied at the Yale School of Art and Architecture from 1945 to 1946, and later attended Syracuse University. In 1953, he moved to New York City, where he became part of the avant-garde art movement. His work includes drawings, paintings, sculptures, and prints.

Zhang Yiming was born in 1978, and is the founder of the Chinese social media platform, Weibo. He graduated from Peking University with a degree in computer science. In 2006, he founded Sina Weibo, which is now one of the most popular social media platforms in China.

Born in New York City, Robert Downey Jr. was raised by his father, actor and filmmaker Robert Downey Sr., and his mother, Elsie Ann Ford. He began acting at the age of five, appearing in his father's films. In 1985, he made his first major appearance in 'Weird Science.' In 2008, he starred as Tony Stark/Iron Man in the blockbuster movie 'Iron Man,' which earned him an Oscar nomination for Best Actor.
